sn36.15:4.1: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha …
sn36.15:4.2: sat down to one side, and said to him:
sn36.15:4.3: “Sir, what is feeling? What’s the origin of feeling? What’s the cessation of feeling? What’s the practice that leads to the cessation of feeling?
sn36.15:4.4: And what is feeling’s gratification, drawback, and escape?”
sn36.15:4.10: The practice that leads to the cessation of feelings is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
sn36.15:4.11: right view, right motivation, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right samādhi.
sn36.15:4.13: The pleasure and happiness that arise from feeling: this is its gratification.
sn36.15:4.14: That feeling is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.
sn36.15:4.15: Removing and giving up desire and greed for feeling: this is its escape.
sn36.15:4.16: But I have also explained the progressive cessation of conditions.
sn36.15:4.17: For someone who has attained the first absorption, speech has ceased. …
sn36.15:4.18: For someone who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, perception and feeling have ceased.
sn36.15:4.19: For a mendicant who has ended the defilements, greed, hate, and delusion have ceased.
sn36.15:4.20: And I have also explained the progressive stilling of conditions.
sn36.15:4.21: For someone who has attained the first absorption, speech has stilled. …
sn36.15:4.22: For someone who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, perception and feeling have stilled.
sn36.15:4.23: For a mendicant who has ended the defilements, greed, hate, and delusion have stilled.
sn36.15:4.24: And I have also explained the progressive tranquilizing of conditions.
sn36.15:4.25: For someone who has attained the first absorption, speech has been tranquilized. …
sn36.15:4.26: For someone who has attained the dimension of infinite space, the perception of form has been tranquilized.
sn36.15:4.27: For someone who has attained the dimension of infinite consciousness, the perception of the dimension of infinite space has been tranquilized.
sn36.15:4.28: For someone who has attained the dimension of nothingness, the perception of the dimension of infinite consciousness has been tranquilized.
sn36.15:4.29: For someone who has attained the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, the perception of the dimension of nothingness has been tranquilized.
sn36.15:4.30: For someone who has attained the cessation of perception and feeling, perception and feeling have been tranquilized.
sn36.15:4.31: For a mendicant who has ended the defilements, greed, hate, and delusion have been tranquilized.”
